questions.text: A 21 year old female was brought to OPD with complaints of fatigue, pallor and headache. Her blood investigations revealed HB- 7.8 gm%, MCV-112 fL, retic count decreased. She is a strict vegan and does not take any supplements. Which of the following histological findings will be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B. The clinical scenario described above is that of Macrocytic Anemia. A strict Vegan diet with an MCV of 112 fL (Normal: 80-100fL) points towards macrocytic anemia.

Highyeild:

The microscopic findings of megaloblastic anemia include hyper-segmented neutrophils(at least 5 lobes), anisocytosis ,oval macrocytes, and pancytopenia. Other abnormalities were seen in the peripheral smear Basophilic stippling (RNA or ribosome fragments) , Cabot's ring (remnants of mitotic spindles), Howell jolly bodies (nuclear remnants). Bone marrow findings— hypercellular marrow, M: E ratio reversal, primitive erythroid precursors with immature nuclei. Giant metamyelocytes, giant megakaryocytes. In B12 / folate deficiency—-Pyrimidine synthesis is halted—DNA Synthesis is halted–defective nuclear maturation Cytoplasmic maturation is normal as heme and globin are normal..hence nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation– Nuclear cytoplasmic Asynchrony

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Hence, options A and B are correct.

Extraedge:

In the case of hyperproliferative anemia(RPI<2.5 ) Iron indices should be checked. Of these MCV and MCH is important. If MCV >100fL-Macrocytosis. Macrocytes can be megaloblastic or non-megaloblastic (normoblasts) for that we need a peripheral smear.. Megaloblasts are large erythroid cells in which nuclear maturation has lagged behind cytoplasmic maturation The normal values of red cell indices are as follows Table 3. Red Blood Cell Indices Index Formula for Calculation Normal Range MCV Hematocrit x 10/RBC count 81-100 fL MCH Hemoglobin x 10/RBC count 26-34 pg MCHC Hemoglobin x 100/he- matocrit 31%-36% RDW Standard deviation of MCV/MCV x 100 11.5%-14.5% Abbreviations: MCH, mean corpuscular hemoglobin; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration; MCV, mean corpuscular volume; RDW, red blood cell distribution width. In vit. B12 deficiency, there will be increased unconjugated bilirubin due to extravascular hemolysis in the spleen.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented to OPD with complaints of fatigue, pallor and weakness for two months. He lives in a hostel and his diet lacks vegetables and other dairy products. Following Blood investigation, the peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following conditions will not lead to these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aplastic Anemia In the given clinical scenario, history suggests that the patient has nutritional deficiency and clinical features like headache, weakness and pallor will have a diagnosis of nutritional anemia. Also, as the given image shows a Cabot ring (remnant of mitotic spindles) which is found in megaloblastic anemia , hence the only option which represents non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia is option C. The causes of megaloblastic anemia with macrocytes are Vitamin B12 Deficiency Folate Deficiency(antifolate drug-Methotrexate) drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine, azidothymidine [AZT] Thiamine deficiency Orotic aciduria. Macrocytes with normoblasts liver disease, Alcoholism, Hypothyroidism, Hemolysis, aplastic anemia. MDS

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Vit B12 deficiency- it is an example of megaloblastic anemia as it will affect erythropoiesis. Option: B. Orotic aciduria- it is due to a defect in UMP synthase which ultimately compromises DNA synthesis and leads to megaloblastic anemia. Option: D . Patients on methotrexate therapy may also show Cabot rings as it will also interfere with DNA synthesis.

Extraedge:

In MDS -sideroblastic anemia, macrocytic anemia, megaloblastic anemia. Alcoholics with thiamine deficiency get megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 28 year old female came to OPD for preconception counseling as she has weakness, and fatigue. On examination, there is pallor, no lymphadenopathy, cyanosis, or clubbing. She is a strict vegan. On her blood investigations, a diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia was established. What will not be laboratory findings in the case of megaloblastic anemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased RDW. In the given question, the female is having megaloblastic anemia as given in the clinical scenario, the following lab finding will be present in this patient- MCV increased Low retic count Increased unconjugated bilirubin due to extravascular hemolysis. Increased RDW. Hence, option D is not a laboratory finding as RDW is increased and not decreased.

Extraedge:

The reticulocyte count is low when there is a defect in the production of RBC and High in case of conditions where there is the destruction of RBC. It is expressed frequently as % of RBCs. Supra vital strains(brilliant cresyl blue, methylene blue) is needed to see the reticulocyte count.

questions.text: A 25 year old female presented with a three-month history of worsening fatigue, dyspnoea on exertion and general weakness. There is no history of fever, or loose stools .she has hyperpigmentation on the dorsum of their hands as shown in the image.on examination, she was pale, and had glossitis, lusterless hair and splenomegaly. Also, her blood investigations revealed pancytopenia, increased MCV, and decreased retic count. Which of the following is the reason behind this finding?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced intracellular glutathione which leads to increased melanin synthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intracellular glutathione which leads to increased melanin synthesis

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduced intracellular glutathione which leads to increased melanin synthesis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduced intracellular glutathione which leads to increased melanin synthesis. Increased MCV, decreased retic count, pancytopenia-like pictures due to affected DNA synthesis, and increased RDW, all these point towards the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. The image shows knuckle hyperpigmentation which can be a clue to early diagnosis of vit B12 deficiency. There is Hyperpigmentation of the extremities especially over the dorsum of hands and feet with accentuation over interphalangeal joints and terminal phalanges associated with pigmentation of the oral mucosa. Note—knuckle hyperpigmentation may be a part of generalized hyperpigmentation as seen in certain ethnic groups, Addions disease, Thyroid disease, and hemochromatosis. The reason for knuckle hyperpigmentation is- reduced intracellular glutathione which leads to increased melanin synthesis and hence leads to hyperpigmentation of the knuckles.(deficiency of vit B12 decreases the level of glutathione, Which activate tyrosinase and thus leads to transfer of melanosomes)

Her routine blood investigation revealed- CBC: HB-8.8 gm%, MCV 110 Fl, retic count 0.5%, TLC- 3,000/mm3, iron S. iron-68 mg/dl, S. ferritin- 150 ug/l. What is the diagnosis for this patient? Vit B12 deficiency In the given clinical scenario, the patient has clinical features of anemia like headache, fatigue and tiredness with pallor on examination. Lab investigation revealed- pancytopenia with low retic count and increased MCV. Normal iron profile. So it points towards the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. Hence the most appropriate answer to this question will be option A.

questions.text: A 28 year old male complains of easy fatigability. Blood investigation was diagnosed to have megaloblastic anemia. Which of the following features does not point towards the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. Splenomegaly. Intravascular hemolysis. Increased retic count Increased MCV Pancytopenia. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,3 In the given clinical scenario, the patient with megaloblastic anemia will have all the following features except intravascular hemolysis and increased retic count. Features of megaloblastic anemia- Anaemia-Fatigue , weight loss, diarrhoea, constipation. unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia -Due to ineffective erythropoiesis and lysis of RBC. Reversible hyperpigmentation Splenomegaly - it is reactive splenomegaly due to extravascular hemolysis. MCV increased due to an increase in the size of the RBC. Pancytopenia can occur as there will be affected DNA synthesis in all the cell lineages.

questions.text: A 31 year old male presented with clinical features like Knuckle hyperpigmentation, fatigue, and weakness after working for some time. His workup showed serum. Vit B12 102 pg/ml along with blood investigation showing anemia. For absorption of vit B12 in the body, what will be the sequence of various carrier molecules that are required for its transport? Transcobalamin-II Haptocorrin Intrinsic protein. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2-3-1 The only source of cobalamin in humans is food of animal origin, for example, meat, fish, and dairy products. The daily requirement of cobalamin is 1-3 ug Body stores are 2-3mg, sufficient for 3-4 years if supply is cut off. The absorption of cobalamin in the diet is as follows Haptocorrin(R Factor) is released in saliva and binds to B12 in the stomach after the action of acid on it. The R factor B12 complex reaches the second part of the duodenum. The complex splits with the help of pancreatic enzymes in the second part of the duodenum. B12 binds with intrinsic factors in the second and third parts of the duodenum. (Intrinsic Factor- it is released from parietal cells or oxyntic cells present in the body and fundus of the stomach.) Intrinsic factor vit B12 complex reaches the ileum and binds to cubilin receptors on ileal cells The cobalamin-IF complex enters the ileal cell, where IF is destroyed. After a delay of about 6 h, the cobalamin appears in portal blood attached to transcobalamin (TC) II. note-Transcobalmin II is synthesized predominantly in the liver. Cubilin also is present in the yolk sac and renal proximal tubular epithelium. Cubilin receptor mutation can be associated with proteinuria. ( Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome or Autosomal Recessive megaloblastic anemia -it is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy. children present with severe megaloblastic anemia with sub nephrotic range proteinuria) Hence, the sequence will be as given in option B. The diagrammatic representation for the same is as follows

Highyeild:

Pernicious anemia - Due to a lack of Intrinsic factor deficiency(gastric atrophy). The median age of onset is 70-80 years. Associated with autoimmune disorders Thyroid disorders, Addison's, type 1 DM, Vitiligo, and hypoparathyroidism . Also associated with -Hypogammaglobulinemia, premature greying, blue eyes, and blood group Africans> Asians. Incidence-120 per 100,000 male:female-1:1.6 Risk of Gastric cancer and Gastrinomas. The gold standard for diagnosis is gastroscopy with biopsy. Serum testing for autoantibodies towards Intrinsic factor and parietal cells.( Anti-parietal cell antibody-sensitive seen in 90% of patients. Anti IF Antibody is specifically seen in 80% of patients ). In juvenile pernicious anemia antiparietal antibodies are absent.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented to OPD because of a problem in remembering things and not being able to recall easily. He also complains of easy fatigability. Blood investigations were done which reveal- Hb- 7.6 gm%, MCV-102 Fl, WBC count- 1200/mm3, S.iron-55 mg/dl, TIBC- 233, s. ferritin- 100 ug/l S. vit B12 level-90 ng/L.his peripheral smear showed the following finding. What will be the adequate treatment for this patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methyl-cobalamin + folic acid. In the given clinical scenario, the patient has clinical features of anemia along with neurological manifestations like dementia, serum iron profile is normal and decreased S. vit B12 level and P/S showing hypersegmented neutrophils points towards the diagnosis of Vit B12 deficiency. Normal serum levels range from 118–738 pmol/L ( 160–1000 ng/ L). In patients with megaloblastic anemia due to cobalamin deficiency, the level is usually <74 pmol/L (100 ng/L). Vitamin B12 is required for the myelination of CNS. Vit B12 deficiency causes Bilateral peripheral neuropathy (initial symptoms), posterior column and lateral column get affected. Optic atrophy and cerebral symptoms including dementia , depression , psychotic symptoms, and cognitive impairment may be seen.

Extraedge:

Indications of starting cobalamin therapy are- established megaloblastic anemia , hematologic abnormality, Neuropathy Prophylactically given to pts with Total gastrectomy or Ileal Resection . pts with gastric reduction surgery or with long term proton pump inhibitor should be given if necessary With treatment, there can be hypokalemia and Thrombocytosis-Aspirin should be considered if platelet Count > 800 × 10 9 /L.

questions.text: A 3 year old male child was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding, and failure to thrive. His parents also say that he does not perform tasks like other children of his age. On examination, pallor was present. Blood workup revealed- pancytopenia, P/S showed hypersegmented neutrophils and macrocytosis of RBC. He was started on Vit B12 and folic acid supplementation but did not improve. Further, the workup revealed increased orotic acid in urine and normal S. ammonia levels. What is the type of inheritance pattern of the condition this patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autosomal recessive. In the given clinical scenario, the three year old child is having failure to thrive, a developmental delay as told by the parents. (Growth retardation) The investigations revealed- megaloblastic anemia but is non-responsive to therapy with Vit B12 and folic acid. Also, orotic acid levels are increased in urine with normal s. ammonia.(other Urea cycle defects have Hyperammonemia) All this points towards the diagnosis of orotic aciduria. (defect in De Novo pyrimidine synthesis. defect in Ump Synthase) Orotic aciduria has a clinical presentation similar to megaloblastic anemia but does not respond to Vit B12 and folic acid supplementation as there is a defect in the DNA synthesis enzyme UMP synthase . It has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Treatment includes supplementation of UMP or uridine triacetate to bypass the mutated enzyme. Extra edge–The two disorders in which B12 , Folic acid metabolism perse is not affected but still there is severe megaloblastic anemia– Orotic Aciduria, Thiamine responsive megaloblastic anemia(Rogers Syndrome)

Extraedge:

The two disorders in which B12 , Folic acid metabolism perse is not affected but still there is severe megaloblastic anemia– Orotic Aciduria, Thiamine responsive megaloblastic anemia(Rogers Syndrome)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is being evaluated for peripheral neuropathy and excessive tiredness. He also is a known case of DM. He is a smoker and alcoholic. Lab investigation reveals the following findings- Hb- 8.5gm/dl; MCV- 110 Fl; MCHC- 34 g/dl; S. homocysteine elevated, s. methyl malonic acid - normal. Which of the following features will not be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reversible dementia. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of folate deficiency as the findings pointing towards it are- anemia, macrocytosis, S. homocysteine elevated, methylmalonic acid – normal In folic acid deficiency, all the features of Vit B12 deficiency are present except the presence of neurological features. The metabolic correctable cause of dementia is Vit B12 deficiency

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A , B and D are incorrect Extra edge-Neuropsychiatric manifestations of B12 Deficiency combined degeneration of Cord, peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia, Optic atrophy(rare), Dementia , Psychosis, Depression.

Extraedge:

Reversible causes of Dementia are Hypothyroidism, Thiamine Deficiency, VitB12 deficiency,normal pressure Hydrocephalus,Subdural Hematoma, Chronic Infection,,Brain tumor, Drug Intoxi cation(BZC, TCA), Autoimmune Encephalopathy. Hence, the answer for the above question regarding the feature that will be absent in this patient will be option C. Peripheral neuropathy is present in this patient which is due to diabetes and not VitB12 deficiency as methyl malonyl acid levels are normal.

questions.text: A 28 year vegetarian male patient presents with a tingling sensation the in fingers of both of his hands. He also feels tired after doing his routine work . He also complains that he is also facing problems in recalling things while he is working. He is admitted for further workup. His lab investigation revealed- Hb- 7.9 g/dl; MCV- 115 Fl; TLC- 3500/mm3. P/S revealed giant platelets with macrocytosis of RBC along with hyper-segmented neutrophils. What will the levels of methyl malonic acid and homocysteine in blood be in the given condition the patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased, increased In the given clinical scenario, it is clear that the patient is suffering from Vit B12 deficiency as- Hb- 7.9 g/dl; TLC- 3500/mm3- pancytopenia MCV- 115 Fl- macrocytosis P/S revealed giant platelets with macrocytosis of RBC along with hyper-segmented neutrophil- suggesting megaloblastic anemia. Neurological symptoms- tingling sensation in fingers of both of his hands, dementia i.e. inability to recall things. In vit B12 deficiency, the level of both S. methylmalonic acid and homocysteine is increased. Homocysteine level is increased as it is not converted to methionine. Methyl malonyl CoA is increased as it is not converted to succinyl CoA with B12 as a cofactor for the enzyme. Hence, both of them will have their levels increased in vit B12 deficiency. The relationship between B12 and folate is depicted in the following flowchart. Methyl malonyl COA is converted to succinyl COA requiring vit B12 Succinyl coA is used in the Krebs cycle of Mitochondria and as a precursor for heme synthesis

Extraedge:

IN B12 DEFICIENCY - Homocysteine cannot be converted to methionine..so homocysteine level is high .MMA is high .methyl THfA is increased and spills in circulation and is high.but an intra cellular deficiency of biologically active THF arises.This is called as folate trap .hence Red cell folate level has to be measured. IN FOLATE DEFICIENCY there is decrease in THFA ,Hence there will be increase in Homocysteine. In B12 AND FOLATE DEFICIENCY –homocysteine is high,5 methyl THF is low and MMAis high .

questions.text: A 62 year old male patient was diagnosed to have Vit B12 deficiency anemia. Schilling test was done to identify the cause for the deficiency. After administering Radiolabelled oral B12 , 24 hour urinary excretion was < 10%. After this, the test was performed in stages which revealed the 24 hour urinary excretion of B12 as follows - Radio-labelled oral B12 +IF- <10% Radio-labelled oral B12 + pancreatic enzymes- >10%. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic insufficiency Schillings test To determine the cause of B12 deficiency. Not used nowadays It's done in 4 stages. Initially Radiolabeled B12 is given to patients followed by an intramuscular dose of vit B12 and 24 hour urine sample is collected. Normal level–at least 10% of Radiolabeled B12 is excreted in urine—-possible diagnosis is Vit B12 dEficiency probably due to poor intake. Impaired absorption < 10%excreted in urine If abnormal repeat the test after giving Intrinsic Factor—-CORRECTED—-- IMPLIES Pernicious anemia Antibiotics—---corrected—- Implies bacterial overgrowth Pancreatic enzymes—corrected— Implies pancreatitis In the given clinical scenario, the patient has Vit B12 deficiency. Schilling’s test was done to determine the cause of the deficiency. After giving pancreatic enzymes, the urinary excretion increased to >10%, the most likely cause of this deficiency will be pancreatic insufficiency.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Pernicious anemia would have been the answer if after giving IF, the urinary excretion would have been increased by>10%, but in this patient, it remains at <10%. Option B. Nutritional B12 deficiency- it would have been the answer if after giving only radiolabeled B12, the urinary excretion of B12 would have increased to >10%. Option D. Bacterial overgrowth syndrome would have been the answer if after giving an antibiotic course of 5 days, the urinary excretion of B12 would have been >10%. But here, there is no such information provided. Hence it cannot be the answer.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presented with tingling and numbness in both her hands. She was admitted for evaluation. Her lab investigation revealed- Hb- 6.5 g/dl; MCV-115 Fl; s. B12 level- 92 pg/ml. P/S revealed- hyper-segmented neutrophil with macrocytosis. After admission, she also started complaining of an inability to feel touch or vibration in her hands. Which of the following structures is responsible for this loss of sensation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dorsal column tract. In the given clinical scenario, the patient presented with neurological symptoms like peripheral neuropathy due to defective myelin synthesis due to Vit B12 deficiency as evidenced by Hb- 6.5 g/dl; MCV-115 Fl- anemia with macrocytosis Serum B12 level- 92 pg/ml- indicates deficiency P/S revealed- hyper-segmented neutrophil with macrocytosis- revealed megaloblastic anemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Spinocerebellar tract is involved in balancing, and unconscious proprioception hence will present with unsteadiness of the gait. Option: B. Lateral corticospinal tract- it will lead to loss of pain and temperature.

Extraedge:

Less SAM(s adenosine methionine due to defect in homocysteine to methionine conversion due to low Vit B12)---demyelination – effects posterior column (loss of vibration and proprioception) and pyramidal tracts (spasticity). Cranial nerves- optic atrophy, anosmia Higher Motor Functions also affected – cognitive impairment and dementia As the structure which is involved in the causation of loss of touch and vibration is asked- it is the dorsal column tract.

questions.text: A 34 year old female, with a known case of hypothyroidism on Levothyroxine 50mcg per day presented with easy fatigability, forgetfulness and tingling over bilateral hands and feet for 2 months. Her Hb was 9.7g/dl with MCV 102 fl. TSH is 2.1 mIU/L. Serum Vit B12 levels are 50pg/ml. What can be the possible cause of anemia in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pernicious anemia This woman is a case of pernicious anemia which causes megaloblastic anemia due to a severe lack of intrinsic factors which is needed for the absorption of vit b12 from food sources. Serum Vit B12 normal value Above 300 pg/mL 200 to 300 pg/mL – Borderline; Below 200 pg/mL – Low(here in question it is 50 pg/ml) Pernicious Anemia:- It is commonly associated with other autoimmune disorders including thyroid disease (thyrotoxicosis, myxedema, Hashimoto disease), vitiligo, hypoparathyroidism, premature graying, blue eye, blood group A & HLA-3. Biochemical analysis HCI secretion ↓ Pepsin secretion ↓ Intrinsic factor secretion ↓ gastrin ↑ Gastric biopsy – shows atrophy of all layers of body and fundus, absence of parietal and chief cells. Types of serum antibodies. Blocking/type I antibody – Prevent combination of Intrinsic Factor and cobalamin – 55% Binding type II antibody – prevent attachment of Intrinsic Factor to ileal mucosa – 35% Parietal cell antibody present in 90% of patients. Clinical Features: Pallor Smooth tongue 3.Cardiac “ hemic” systolic murmur Hepatomegaly. Neurologic picture B12 deficiency ranges from mental inattentiveness to severe mental confusion with or without dorsal and lateral column signs (subacute combined degeneration). These signs are reversible with cobalamin therapy. Tongue in Vit B12 deficiency a. Macroglossia b. Atrophic glossitis (smooth tongue due to Loss of papillae) c. Moeller’s glossitis (A superficial form of glossitis marked by irregular red patches on the tongue and sensitivity to hot or spicy food) d. Sore Tongue (Red and inflamed) e. Beefy tongue 7.Neurological Findings in B12 Deficiency a. Peripheral nerves - Glove and stocking paraesthesia b. Spinal cord Subacute combined degeneration Posterior columns – diminished vibration and Proprioception iii. Corticospinal tracts – upper motor neuron signs c. Cerebrum - Dementia (reversible dementia) d. Cranial nerve - Optic atrophy e. Autonomic neuropathy

Extraedge:

–In cooleys, there is microcytic anemia seen in Beta Thalassemia major
